definition: Epigenetics refers to heritable and reversible changes in gene function that do not involve alterations in the DNA sequence.
example: Epigenetic regulation contributes to cell-type–specific gene expression.
source: NHGRI Talking Glossary of Genetic Terms; Nature Reviews Genetics

definition: DNA methylation is the covalent addition of a methyl group to DNA, typically at CpG dinucleotides, and is associated with transcriptional repression.
example: Aberrant DNA methylation was observed in tumor samples.
source: NHGRI Talking Glossary of Genetic Terms; NCBI Bookshelf – Molecular Biology of the Cell

definition: Histone modifications are chemical changes to histone proteins that influence chromatin structure and gene expression.
example: Histone acetylation correlated with transcriptional activation.
source: Nature Reviews Molecular Cell Biology

definition: ATAC-seq is a sequencing-based assay that uses a transposase to identify regions of open chromatin genome-wide.
example: ATAC-seq revealed regulatory elements active in immune cells.
source: Nature Reviews Genetics; EMBL-EBI Training – Epigenomics

definition: ChIP-seq combines chromatin immunoprecipitation with sequencing to map protein–DNA interactions and histone modifications.
example: ChIP-seq identified transcription factor binding sites.
source: NHGRI Talking Glossary of Genetic Terms; Nature Reviews Genetics

definition: Single-cell omics encompasses technologies that profile genomic, transcriptomic, epigenomic, or proteomic features at single-cell resolution.
example: Single-cell omics resolved cellular heterogeneity within tumors.
source: Nature Reviews Genetics; EMBL-EBI Training – Single-cell

definition: Single-cell RNA sequencing measures gene expression at the level of individual cells, enabling identification of distinct cell populations.
example: scRNA-seq identified rare immune cell subsets.
source: NHGRI Talking Glossary of Genetic Terms; Nature Reviews Genetics

definition: A unique molecular identifier is a short random sequence used to tag individual molecules and correct for amplification bias.
example: UMIs were used to deduplicate PCR artifacts.
source: Nature Reviews Genetics; EMBL-EBI Training – Single-cell

definition: Spatial transcriptomics refers to methods that measure gene expression while preserving spatial information within tissue sections.
example: Spatial transcriptomics localized gene expression to tumor margins.
source: Nature Reviews Genetics; EMBL-EBI Training – Spatial Omics

definition: Metabolomics is the comprehensive analysis of small-molecule metabolites in biological systems.
example: Metabolomics revealed alterations in energy metabolism.
source: Nature Reviews Molecular Cell Biology; EMBL-EBI Training – Metabolomics

definition: Lipidomics is the large-scale study of cellular lipid species, their structures, and biological functions.
example: Lipidomics detected changes in membrane lipid composition.
source: Nature Reviews Molecular Cell Biology

definition: Glycomics is the comprehensive analysis of glycans and glycan-related structures in biological systems.
example: Glycomics revealed altered glycosylation patterns in cancer.
source: Nature Reviews Molecular Cell Biology

definition: Metagenomics involves sequencing and analysis of genetic material recovered directly from environmental or host-associated microbial communities.
example: Metagenomics characterized the gut microbial community.
source: NHGRI Talking Glossary of Genetic Terms; Nature Reviews Microbiology

definition: The microbiome refers to the collective genomes and activities of microorganisms inhabiting a specific environment.
example: Disruption of the gut microbiome was associated with disease.
source: NHGRI Talking Glossary of Genetic Terms

definition: Functional genomics aims to understand gene and protein function using high-throughput experimental approaches.
example: Functional genomics linked gene perturbations to phenotypes.
source: Nature Reviews Genetics

definition: Epigenetics refers to heritable and reversible changes in gene function that do not involve alterations in the DNA sequence.
example: Epigenetic regulation contributes to cell-type–specific gene expression.
source: NHGRI Talking Glossary of Genetic Terms; Nature Reviews Genetics

example: Lipidomics detected changes in membrane lipid composition.
source: Nature Reviews Molecular Cell Biology

definition: Glycomics is the comprehensive analysis of glycans and glycan-related structures in biological systems.
example: Glycomics revealed altered glycosylation patterns in cancer.
source: Nature Reviews Molecular Cell Biology

definition: Metagenomics involves sequencing and analysis of genetic material recovered directly from environmental or host-associated microbial communities.
example: Metagenomics characterized the gut microbial community.
source: NHGRI Talking Glossary of Genetic Terms; Nature Reviews Microbiology

definition: The microbiome refers to the collective genomes and activities of microorganisms inhabiting a specific environment.
example: Disruption of the gut microbiome was associated with disease.
source: NHGRI Talking Glossary of Genetic Terms

definition: Functional genomics aims to understand gene and protein function using high-throughput experimental approaches.
example: Functional genomics linked gene perturbations to phenotypes.
source: Nature Reviews Genetics

definition: Epigenetics refers to heritable and reversible changes in gene function that do not involve alterations in the DNA sequence.
example: Epigenetic regulation contributes to cell-type–specific gene expression.
source: NHGRI Talking Glossary of Genetic Terms; Nature Reviews Genetics

definition: DNA methylation is the covalent addition of a methyl group to DNA, typically at CpG dinucleotides, and is associated with transcriptional repression.
example: Aberrant DNA methylation was observed in tumor samples.
source: NHGRI Talking Glossary of Genetic Terms; NCBI Bookshelf – Molecular Biology of the Cell

definition: Histone modifications are chemical changes to histone proteins that influence chromatin structure and gene expression.
example: Histone acetylation correlated with transcriptional activation.
source: Nature Reviews Molecular Cell Biology

definition: ATAC-seq is a sequencing-based assay that uses a transposase to identify regions of open chromatin genome-wide.
example: ATAC-seq revealed regulatory elements active in immune cells.
source: Nature Reviews Genetics; EMBL-EBI Training – Epigenomics

definition: ChIP-seq combines chromatin immunoprecipitation with sequencing to map protein–DNA interactions and histone modifications.
example: ChIP-seq identified transcription factor binding sites.
source: NHGRI Talking Glossary of Genetic Terms; Nature Reviews Genetics

definition: Single-cell omics encompasses technologies that profile genomic, transcriptomic, epigenomic, or proteomic features at single-cell resolution.
example: Single-cell omics resolved cellular heterogeneity within tumors.
source: Nature Reviews Genetics; EMBL-EBI Training – Single-cell

definition: Single-cell RNA sequencing measures gene expression at the level of individual cells, enabling identification of distinct cell populations.
example: scRNA-seq identified rare immune cell subsets.
source: NHGRI Talking Glossary of Genetic Terms; Nature Reviews Genetics

definition: A unique molecular identifier is a short random sequence used to tag individual molecules and correct for amplification bias.
example: UMIs were used to deduplicate PCR artifacts.
source: Nature Reviews Genetics; EMBL-EBI Training – Single-cell

definition: Spatial transcriptomics refers to methods that measure gene expression while preserving spatial information within tissue sections.
example: Spatial transcriptomics localized gene expression to tumor margins.
source: Nature Reviews Genetics; EMBL-EBI Training – Spatial Omics

definition: Metabolomics is the comprehensive analysis of small-molecule metabolites in biological systems.
example: Metabolomics revealed alterations in energy metabolism.
source: Nature Reviews Molecular Cell Biology; EMBL-EBI Training – Metabolomics

definition: Single-cell omics encompasses technologies that profile genomic, transcriptomic, epigenomic, or proteomic features at single-cell resolution.
example: Single-cell omics resolved cellular heterogeneity within tumors.
source: Nature Reviews Genetics; EMBL-EBI Training – Single-cell

definition: Single-cell RNA sequencing measures gene expression at the level of individual cells, enabling identification of distinct cell populations.
example: scRNA-seq identified rare immune cell subsets.
source: NHGRI Talking Glossary of Genetic Terms; Nature Reviews Genetics

definition: A unique molecular identifier is a short random sequence used to tag individual molecules and correct for amplification bias.
example: UMIs were used to deduplicate PCR artifacts.
source: Nature Reviews Genetics; EMBL-EBI Training – Single-cell

definition: Spatial transcriptomics refers to methods that measure gene expression while preserving spatial information within tissue sections.
example: Spatial transcriptomics localized gene expression to tumor margins.
source: Nature Reviews Genetics; EMBL-EBI Training – Spatial Omics

definition: Metabolomics is the comprehensive analysis of small-molecule metabolites in biological systems.
example: Metabolomics revealed alterations in energy metabolism.
source: Nature Reviews Molecular Cell Biology; EMBL-EBI Training – Metabolomics

definition: Lipidomics is the large-scale study of cellular lipid species, their structures, and biological functions.
example: Lipidomics detected changes in membrane lipid composition.
source: Nature Reviews Molecular Cell Biology

definition: Glycomics is the comprehensive analysis of glycans and glycan-related structures in biological systems.
example: Glycomics revealed altered glycosylation patterns in cancer.
source: Nature Reviews Molecular Cell Biology

definition: Metagenomics involves sequencing and analysis of genetic material recovered directly from environmental or host-associated microbial communities.
example: Metagenomics characterized the gut microbial community.
source: NHGRI Talking Glossary of Genetic Terms; Nature Reviews Microbiology

definition: The microbiome refers to the collective genomes and activities of microorganisms inhabiting a specific environment.
example: Disruption of the gut microbiome was associated with disease.
source: NHGRI Talking Glossary of Genetic Terms

definition: Functional genomics aims to understand gene and protein function using high-throughput experimental approaches.
example: Functional genomics linked gene perturbations to phenotypes.
source: Nature Reviews Genetics

definition: Epigenetics refers to heritable and reversible changes in gene function that do not involve alterations in the DNA sequence.
example: Epigenetic regulation contributes to cell-type–specific gene expression.
source: NHGRI Talking Glossary of Genetic Terms; Nature Reviews Genetics

definition: DNA methylation is the covalent addition of a methyl group to DNA, typically at CpG dinucleotides, and is associated with transcriptional repression.
example: Aberrant DNA methylation was observed in tumor samples.
source: NHGRI Talking Glossary of Genetic Terms; NCBI Bookshelf – Molecular Biology of the Cell

definition: Histone modifications are chemical changes to histone proteins that influence chromatin structure and gene expression.
example: Histone acetylation correlated with transcriptional activation.
source: Nature Reviews Molecular Cell Biology

definition: ATAC-seq is a sequencing-based assay that uses a transposase to identify regions of open chromatin genome-wide.
example: ATAC-seq revealed regulatory elements active in immune cells.
source: Nature Reviews Genetics; EMBL-EBI Training – Epigenomics

definition: ChIP-seq combines chromatin immunoprecipitation with sequencing to map protein–DNA interactions and histone modifications.
example: ChIP-seq identified transcription factor binding sites.
source: NHGRI Talking Glossary of Genetic Terms; Nature Reviews Genetics
